title: Simulated World Series: Nationals' Anibal Sanchez is superb in Game 3
text:
CLOSE What I'm Hearing: USA TODAY Sports’ Bob Nightengale was in the Houston Astros clubhouse following a devastating loss to the Nationals in Game 2, but he describes a positive mood throughout the team. USA TODAY

How will this year's World Series play out? Using the Dynasty League Baseball online simulation, USA TODAY Sports' Steve Gardner and DLB designer Mike Cieslinski will pre-play each game to provide some insight into the key matchups and strategy fans can expect to see in the Fall Classic.

Game 3: Houston Astros at Washington Nationals

WASHINGTON — In a World Series filled with ace starting pitchers, Anibal Sanchez proved he deserves to be mentioned in the same breath with Gerrit Cole, Justin Verlander, Max Scherzer and Stephen Strasburg.

Sanchez limited the mighty Houston Astros offense to one run and three hits over 7⅓ innings as the Washington Nationals rolled to a 4-1 victory in Game 3 of USA TODAY's annual Simulated World Series.

Sanchez wasn't overly dominant, striking out only five Astros hitters, but he never got into any serious trouble the entire game — yielding only a solo home run to Carlos Correa before being lifted with one out in the eighth.

BOX SCORE: Nationals 4, Astros 1

PLAY-BY-PLAY: Sanchez, two relievers silence Astros' bats

The Nationals broke a scoreless tie in the third inning against Houston starter Zack Greinke when right fielder Josh Reddick misplayed Trea Turner's line drive into a three-base error that allowed Sanchez to score from first base.

Juan Soto plated the Nats' second run with a one-out single that scored Turner.

The only other scoring in the game came on Victor Robles' two-out, two-run homer off Greinke in the bottom of the sixth.

To close things out, the Nationals relied on their two top relievers for 1⅔ shutout innings. Lefty Sean Doolittle got the final two outs in the eighth and Daniel Hudson stuck out the side in the ninth to earn the save.

A screenshot of Victor Robles' two-run home run in Game 3 of USA TODAY's Simulated World Series. The target down the left-field line is where the ball landed in the stands. (Photo: Dynasty League Baseball)

Previous Sim results

GAME 1: Astros 4, Nationals 0

GAME 2: Astros 10, Nationals 2

What to watch in (the actual) Game 3

— Pitching is primary: With the potential for three games in three days as the World Series moves to Washington, both teams will need strong efforts out of their No. 3 starters to avoid taxing their bullpens too much over the next two days.

Sanchez was one of the best pitchers in the majors at limiting hard contact during the regular season at 31.6%. Since he doesn't have a high strikeout rate (7.3 K/9), limiting the damage opposing hitters do when they make contact is the key to his success.

Greinke wasn't bad in the simulated game — his defense let him down with two unearned runs — but Sanchez was better.

— No DH: The Astros didn't have rookie slugger Yordan Alvarez in the lineup for Game 3, but their offense doesn't suffer as much as a typical American League team would with Greinke in the lineup.

Among pitchers with at least 50 plate appearances, Greinke's .277 average led the majors — as did his three home runs and .596 slugging percentage. (The second-best slugging percentage by any pitcher with that many plate appearances was Colorado's German Marquez at .362.)

Greinke went 0-for-2 in Sim Series Game 3, but he could be a factor in the real game.

— Lift-off for Astros? Houston will have its best chance of the series to get its running game going with Sanchez paired up with catcher Kurt Suzuki. According to Dynasty League Baseball's 2019 player ratings, the Nationals' right-hander has a C+ grade for his pickoff move and a +4 rating (the worst a pitcher can have) in delivering the ball to the plate with runners on base.

Likewise, Suzuki has a +3 rating for his throwing arm, having cut down only 10% of runners attempting to steal during the season. Look for the Astros to try to steal whenever they get a runner on first base in Game 3.

Simulate your own World Series. Get a FREE one-month subscription to Dynasty League Baseball online by going to DynastyLeagueBaseball.com, selecting the monthly option and entering code USA2 at checkout.
description: Nationals starter Anibal Sanchez allowed one run and three hits as  Washington held off the Houston Astros in Game 3 of the Simulated World Series.
